results.headline: Load Up. Remove Clothes. Then Try Not to Lose Head.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Shooter

results.summary_short: Muscles bulge and heads explode in this thoroughly reprehensible, satisfyingly violent entertainment about men and guns and things that go boom.

results.headline: Who Else but an Old Buddy Can Tell How Lost You Are?

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Reign Over Me

results.summary_short: “Reign Over Me” uses the rhythms and moods of comedy to explore, and also to contain, overpowering feelings of loss.

results.headline: Iraqi Roused From Sleep Wakes Up to a Nightmare
results.display_title: The Prisoner or: How I Planned to Kill Tony Blair

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Prisoner or: How I Planned to Kill Tony Blair

results.summary_short: In “The Prisoner,” an Iraqi journalist shares his anguish, his outrage, his fear, his despair, his hope...his Iraq.

results.headline: A Nanny Who Can Be Murder at the Piano

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Page Turner

results.summary_short: In “The Page Turner,” rather big questions vibrate inside this rather small film, shaking it like a V-8 engine dropped in a Volkswagen Bug.

results.headline: The Player Who Played as Kubrick

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Color Me Kubrick

results.summary_short: Even if it doesn’t add up to more than a fitfully amusing collection of comic sketches, “Color Me Kubrick” is a platform for John Malkovich to burst into lurid purple flame.

results.headline: Where Heart of Darkness Begets Head of Nuttiness

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Cobra Verde

results.summary_short: Connoisseurs of craziness need wait no longer. “Cobra Verde” is here in all its feral, baffling glory.

results.headline: Making Waves in a Tough Community

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Pride

results.summary_short: In the idealistic “Pride,” a swim coach leads an inner-city recreational center’s swim team to victory.

results.headline: Surviving in the Aftermath of Vietnam

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Journey From the Fall

results.summary_short: Set amid the chaos of late-70s Vietnam, “Journey From the Fall” recounts one family’s endurance in a sturdy, old-movie style.

results.headline: Ready to Figuratively Rock and Pretend Roll

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Air Guitar Nation

results.summary_short: Alexandra Lipsitz’s breezy competition documentary “Air Guitar Nation” contains droll humor and wild performances that are hard to resist.

results.headline: The Hustle and Bustle of Love

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Boy Culture

results.summary_short: Q. Allan Brocka’s absorbing drama follows an emotionally repressed gay hustler as he rebels against the obsessions of his culture.

results.headline: Turtle Power of the CGI Variety

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of TMNT

results.summary_short: In “TMNT,” these superheroes in a half shell have firmly been co-opted by the industry their creators once sought to spoof.

results.headline: Box to the Future

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Last Mimzy

results.summary_short: Invoking Lewis Carroll, “E.T.” and Tibetan Buddhism, “The Last Mimzy” is an overstuffed yet warmhearted sci-fi drama.

results.headline: Deadly Reminiscence

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Memory

results.summary_short: This sluggish psychological thriller advances more slowly than a cure for Alzheimer’s.

results.headline: A Short War Lives Long in the Minds of Soldiers

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Blessed by Fire

results.summary_short: Tristan Bauer’s film portrays the Falklands War in 1982 as a mismanaged, vainglorious spasm of nationalism.

results.headline: A Killer Kind of Comedy
results.display_title: Behind the Mask: The Rise of Leslie Vernon

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Behind the Mask: The Rise of Leslie Vernon

results.summary_short: The serial-killer parody “Behind the Mask: The Rise of Leslie Vernon” has nerve, rapier-sharp observations and a firm grasp of tone.

results.headline: Action in Kazakhstan

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Nomad

results.summary_short: “Nomad: The Warrior” looks and feels like an old-school American western. Not a great western, but a reasonably good example of that genre.

results.headline: Murder by Dummy

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Dead Silence

results.summary_short: The playfully self-aware touches of “Dead Silence” distract from its leaden pacing, three too many final twists and various behavioral idiocies.

results.headline: A Happy Housewife Does the Time Warp, and Madness Ensues

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Premonition

results.summary_short: The sloppy, absent-minded “Premonition” is a step back in time and a giant leap backward for Sandra Bullock.

results.headline: A Concept, a Host, an Island and People Who Eat People?
results.display_title: American Cannibal: The Road to Reality

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of American Cannibal: The Road to Reality

results.summary_short: This documentary about the business of reality television illustrates the premise that if you lie down with dogs, you wake up with fleas.

results.headline: Orphans Searching for Hope

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of My Brother

results.summary_short: “My Brother” is billed as the tale of two poor, orphaned siblings, but it wants to be much more than that.
